messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:52): vcard.org, vcard.net, vevent.org, and vevent.net are all squatted
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:52): sigh
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:56): No country code .rd either
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:58): i don't like splitting words with dots like that
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (03:58): Domain Information
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (03:58): Status: Not Registered
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:59): ai guess i'll go with http://n.whatwg.org/vcard and http://n.whatwg.org/vevent
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e - inventing yet another vocabulary space?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:59): no, just finding URLs for the vcard and vevent vocabularies
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:00): so they can be identified in microdata and so they can be converted to rdf
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (04:00): ht.ml.vcard would have been sooo nice :/

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e - http://microformats.org/profile/hcard and http://microformats.org/profile/hcalendar already define the vcard and vevent vocabularies in the context of HTML (microformats etc.)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:00): and work as URLs for when converting to RDF
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:00): with the proper #term suffix and everything
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): no need to reinvent your own new URLs
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): e.g. http://microformats.org/profile/hcard#fn
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): that's for hcard and hcalendar though
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): and http://microformats.org/profile/hcalendar#dtstart
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): also, the #foo stuff works differently in microdata
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): hcard = vcard in HTML
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): hcalendar = icalendar and vevent in HTML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): no, hcard = vcard in class="" in HTML
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:01): the "h" = HTML
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): i'm talking about microdata
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): i mean, i don't mind reusing that URL if you want
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:02): but it doesn't seem that you'd want me to
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I'll clarify the profiles to make it clear they're not just for class
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:02): notes a to-do

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:03): as the hCard 1.0.1 and hCalendar 1.0.1 separate the notion of the vocabularies from the host language extension points (e.g. class in HTML3, HTML4, and HTML5, and microdata in HTML5)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): k, i'll use http://microformats.org/profile/hcard
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): seems confusing to me to have two nearly-identical vocabularies with different conversions to RDF using the same vocabulary name, but whatever
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:04): how will the conversions to RDF be different?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:04): I'm not sure I understand
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, if you have an "ideal" conversion to RDF already in mind, I am willing to look into re-using it.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:05): I don't see any good reason for there to be two different conversions for hCard/vCard to RDF.

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:05): and the #foo suffix on the URLs was done deliberately to be compatible with RDF style URLs - I'd advise keeping that compatibility (unless you have a very good reason to be different).

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:06): short names converted to rdf from microdata, e.g. "fn" in vcard, end up looking like "http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml/vocab#http%3A%2F%2Fmicroformats.org%2Fprofile%2Fhcard%23fn"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:06): s/vocab/custom/
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:06): whoa that's nasty
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:07): i can't see another way to prevent people from ending up using the full names when roubd-tripping
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:07): round
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:09): is round-tripping a requirement? based on which use case?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:10): exporting to legacy formats (like .vcf) inevitably will result in some loss of fidelity
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:10): round-tripping isn't a requirement, it's just something that's likely to happen that it's important we don't let screw us up
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:10): I disagree
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:10): ok
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:10): if there isn't a use case for it
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:10): then round-tripping unnecessarily compromises the design
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:10): both .vcf and .rdf/xml are legacy stream formats IMHO
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:11): i'm talking about round-tripping through a triple store
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:11): which sems highly likely to occur if rdf and microdata ever get used together
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:13): I don't know - do you have any existing examples of HTML (of any kind) being produced from a triple-store?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:13): sure, dbpedia.org for example
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:13): I'm not sure that a triple-store isn't lossy in the first place
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:13): or anything metaweb produces
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:14): I bet the HTML produced from those is lossy compared to the HTML semantics they consumed to create the triple-store.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:14): microdata is (amongst other things) an rdf serialisation, so i don't see any reason why it'd be lossy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:14): it's not like microformats in that respect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:14): microformats -> rdf is definitely lossy, sure
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:14): sort of
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:14): no that's not lossy
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:14): because it works with URLs
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:14): for each term
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:15): so what's lossy then?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:15): it's the reverse that's lossy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:15): i'm very confused as to what you're saying
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:15): rdf -> microdata
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:15): the end result
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:15): oh sure, arbitrary rdf to microdata can be lossy, e.g. you lose datatypes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:15): i'm talking about microdata -> rdf -> microdata
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:15): but once it enters a triple store, who knows what else gets added to it
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:15): that's my point

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:16): my point is just that i don't want people writing <span itemprop="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard#fn">...</span> and expecting it to be treated the same as <span itemprop="fn">...</span>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:17): because that's an interop nightmare
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:17): the whole point of microdata is that you don't have ambiguity of this nature
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:17): you can do string compares at each stage of the way
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:18): without needing any built-in knowledge of the vocabularies
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): why not just define itemprop="fn" to be a shorthand for itemprop="http://microformats.org/profile/hcard#fn"
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): basically, define the predefined vocabularies in terms of microformats profile URLs
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): make them equivalent
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): rather than needlessly slightly different
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:18): because then you need to know the vocabulary to do anything
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): that applies to *any* predefined vocabulary
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:18): based on that argument you should toss all predefined vocabs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:18): no, the whole point of microdata is to fix the problem that microformats had whereby you need knowledge of the vocabulary to do _anything_
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:19): which the predefined vocabularies replicate
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:19): ergo, drop the predefined vocabularies from HTML5 microdata
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:19): what predefiend vocabularies?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:19): html5 doesn't have predefined vocabularies
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:19): they've been gone for hours

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:20): my point is that with microdata, you can parse any microdata into a tree, then compare it to another tree, and e.g. say whether they're the same or not, without knowing the vocabularies
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:20): but if we start saying that multiple strings mean the same thing, we've lost that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:20): and that's a problem
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:22): "gone for hours"?!?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:22): yes, keep up :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:23): r4066 removed them
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:23): LOL - wow - ok, right then.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:23): will re-read the section later tonight
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:23): more than hours in fact, almost a day and a half :-)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:24): has been busy writing up and running #microformats value-class-pattern date and time separation test cases.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (04:24): (as part of the inclusion of required value-class-pattern support into hCard 1.0.1 and hCalendar 1.0.1)
